results.title: Intransit
results.creator_credit: Isabel Perez, Mike Daly and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
A boy journeys into his own dark underworld where he is confronted by the vengeful father of his imagination.
Features Louis Westgarth as Ben, James Hagen as Ben’s father and Humphrey Westgarth as young Ben.

results.title: Into the night
results.creator_credit: Rachel Clements, Melissa Johnston, Tony Krawitz and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A lost and fragile boy new to the streets. A wary teenager just thinking about the money. A wealthy man playing out a delicate and lonely game. Over one night their lives intersect in unexpected ways, blurring the line between betrayer and betrayed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rachel Clements, Melissa Johnston, Tony Krawitz and AFTRS

results.title: Binary
results.creator_credit: Rachel Roberts, Mike Daly and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Trapped in a cell of fear, Claire’s longing for connection propels her beyond the known world.
The world of Binary is neither a particular time or place, it is Claire’s headspace. The images, sounds and content of the film always represent Claire’s mental state, they are completely subjective. Digital visual effects were employed in the production of Binary to assist this approach and to portray Claire’s increasingly unstable view of her world.
Features Susan Prior as Claire and Briden Aspinall as the young girl.

results.title: The Two-wheeled time machine
results.creator_credit: Miriam Stein, David Lowe and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Henry Howard has discovered a way to stay young forever but life doesn’t seem worth living without his childhood sweetheart, Alice. Risking old age, Henry returns to convince her to join him.
Cast includes Matt Day as Henry, and Essie Davis as Alice (aged 19-35) and Jacki Weaver as Alice (49-76).

group_siblings.title: Rock et man
group_siblings.creator_credit: Leone Knight, Adrian Van de Velde and AFTRS

results.title: Rock et man
results.creator_credit: Leone Knight, Adrian Van de Velde and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
The allegedly true story of Darwin Edward Cole, a serial killer on death row, who claims to have deflected Tesla’s Comet from its intersection with the earth’s orbit, thereby saving the world from certain destruction. He also claims to have returned with a new virus that only kills “deviants”, thus ridding the world of another plague.
He confesses to the murders and insists that he is sane, refusing all attempts to have himself declared unfit to plead.

results.title: Rabbit on the moon
results.brief_description:
Italians are the largest group of non Anglo Celtic migrants in Australia, totalling nearly one million people. Yet, like most of these migrants, they are either constantly misrepresented or not represented at all on Australian screens.
Australia, 1971. “Rabbit on the moon” is a fairy tale about a northern Italian girl growing up in suburban Australia as seven year old, Italian born Guiseppina (Aurelia Eneide) encounters the painful realisation that she is living in a dual society.

results.title: Peel
results.brief_description: A red-headed family’s drive in the countryside begins an intrigue of awesome belligerence and obstinacy. This short student drama from the director of ‘The Piano’ (2003) was the winner of the Palme d’Or for best short film at Cannes in 1986. Original format 16 mm/colour.

results.title: Mr Ikegami's flight
results.brief_description: Mr Ikegami is in Sydney on business. Back in Tokyo, his wife Seisuko is expecting their first child. A tale of divided loyalties. Features Kazuhiro Muroyama as Mr Ikegami. Japanese/English with English subtitles. Original format 35 mm

results.title: Egg
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Anne Gilhooly and Nicole Mitchell
results.brief_description:
An elderly woman living alone in her suburban family home makes a friend - a fallen bird’s egg she finds in the local park. She takes Egg into her home, and into her heart.
A sensual and evocative film about lonliness, life and love.
Features Paulette Perry as the woman.
